page.title: 13Employment
page.content: Croda Croda started in 1925 in a disused waterworks making lanolin owned by Mr. Crowe and Mr. Dawe. In 1931 they made their first profit and found out lanolin prevents rust. In 1939/45 helped out making things in the war. In 1950 opened a business in New York. In 1955 they bought Cowick Hall and used it as head quarters. In 1964 they became a public company. Now they had 40 factories in Britain. From 1964-1974 the company became 50 times bigger. Croda also bought other chemical industries. From 1974 to 1980 it was a bad spell. In 1985 Croda was 60 years old. Around 6000 staff work at Croda worldwide. Croda means Crowe Dawe after the people who started it. Croda's profits are now around 20 million pounds.
